posts.title: Working a Desk Job? 4 Health Tips for the Office
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"1. Take Regular Breaks

Long periods of sitting down and looking at a computer monitor or pouring over paperwork can be taxing on the body and the mind. Even though you might be reluctant to take advantage of breaks due to your workload, it’s important that you do. Taking even short breaks can actually improve focus, boost energy and increase your overall productivity and sense of wellbeing.

2. Bring Your Own Lunch to Work

A good step towards greater wellness at work is to bring a healthy lunch with you and avoid eating out or being tempted by unhealthy office treats. When lunch hour rolls around, try to find a place other than your desk to eat such as an outdoor park or common area. Getting out of the office for a short period can provide some much needed relief and get your body moving.

3. Take the Stairs

If you work in a multi-story office, skip the elevator and head for the stairs. Many studies indicate that humans who take at least 10,000 steps per day enjoy greater health. However, sitting at your desk all day can make that a tall order, so take advantage of those stairs to boost your heart rate and help strengthen the core and leg muscles.

4. Create a "Workout" Work Space

If company policies allow for it, you can create a mini workout zone right in your office. Consider investing in a standing desk or a treadmill that can double as a work zone when you need to get some exercise and still be productive on company time. Mini steppers are also popular options that can fit right under your desk and can help you enjoy a healthy workplace.

![5777a4a375f1786af00535a17e958dd1](/content/images/2018/03/5777a4a375f1786af00535a17e958dd1.jpg)

"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
1. Take Regular Breaks

Long periods of sitting down and looking at a computer monitor or pouring over paperwork can be taxing on the body and the mind. Even though you might be reluctant to take advantage of breaks due to your workload, it’s important that you do. Taking even short breaks can actually improve focus, boost energy and increase your overall productivity and sense of wellbeing.

  1. Bring Your Own Lunch to Work

A good step towards greater wellness at work is to bring a healthy lunch with you and avoid eating out or being tempted by unhealthy office treats. When lunch hour rolls around, try to find a place other than your desk to eat such as an outdoor park or common area. Getting out of the office for a short period can provide some much needed relief and get your body moving.

  1. Take the Stairs

If you work in a multi-story office, skip the elevator and head for the stairs. Many studies indicate that humans who take at least 10,000 steps per day enjoy greater health. However, sitting at your desk all day can make that a tall order, so take advantage of those stairs to boost your heart rate and help strengthen the core and leg muscles.

  1. Create a "Workout" Work Space

If company policies allow for it, you can create a mini workout zone right in your office. Consider investing in a standing desk or a treadmill that can double as a work zone when you need to get some exercise and still be productive on company time. Mini steppers are also popular options that can fit right under your desk and can help you enjoy a healthy workplace.
posts.plaintext:
1. Take Regular Breaks

Long periods of sitting down and looking at a computer monitor or pouring over
paperwork can be taxing on the body and the mind. Even though you might be
reluctant to take advantage of breaks due to your workload, it’s important that
you do. Taking even short breaks can actually improve focus, boost energy and
increase your overall productivity and sense of wellbeing.

 2. Bring Your Own Lunch to Work

A good step towards greater wellness at work is to bring a healthy lunch with
you and avoid eating out or being tempted by unhealthy office treats. When lunch
hour rolls around, try to find a place other than your desk to eat such as an
outdoor park or common area. Getting out of the office for a short period can
provide some much needed relief and get your body moving.

 3. Take the Stairs

If you work in a multi-story office, skip the elevator and head for the stairs.
Many studies indicate that humans who take at least 10,000 steps per day enjoy
greater health. However, sitting at your desk all day can make that a tall
order, so take advantage of those stairs to boost your heart rate and help
strengthen the core and leg muscles.

 4. Create a "Workout" Work Space

If company policies allow for it, you can create a mini workout zone right in
your office. Consider investing in a standing desk or a treadmill that can
double as a work zone when you need to get some exercise and still be productive
on company time. Mini steppers are also popular options that can fit right under
your desk and can help you enjoy a healthy workplace.
posts.custom_excerpt: Long periods of sitting down and looking at a computer monitor or pouring over paperwork can be taxing on the body and the mind.

posts.title: Back Strengthening Exercise - Arm Lifts
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"_These exercises should only be performed after evaluation by a qualified medical professional and under their instruction. Should you experience pain or discomfort while doing an exercise, stop immediately._


<video width="640" controls >
  <source src="https://assets.imatrix.com/videos/chiro/back/back_strengthening_exercise_arm_lifts/back_strengthening_exercise_arm_lifts_hd.webm" type="video/webm" />
  <source src="https://assets.imatrix.com/videos/chiro/back/back_strengthening_exercise_arm_lifts/back_strengthening_exercise_arm_lifts_hd.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
  <source src="https://assets.imatrix.com/videos/chiro/back/back_strengthening_exercise_arm_lifts/back_strengthening_exercise_arm_lifts_hd.ogv" type="video/ogg" />
  Your browser doesn't support HTML5 video tag.
</video>

---

### Exercise Instructions

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your back straight. Raise your right arm forward, finishing with your arm in line with your body. Send energy all the way up your spine and out through your arm and hand. Relax and return to the starting position. Repeat with the other arm.

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your back straight. Raise your right arm forward, finishing with your arm in line with your body. Send energy all the way up your spine and out through your arm and hand. Relax and return to the starting position. Repeat with the other arm."}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
These exercises should only be performed after evaluation by a qualified medical professional and under their instruction. Should you experience pain or discomfort while doing an exercise, stop immediately.

Exercise Instructions

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your back straight. Raise your right arm forward, finishing with your arm in line with your body. Send energy all the way up your spine and out through your arm and hand. Relax and return to the starting position. Repeat with the other arm.

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your back straight. Raise your right arm forward, finishing with your arm in line with your body. Send energy all the way up your spine and out through your arm and hand. Relax and return to the starting position. Repeat with the other arm.

Exercise Instructions
Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your
weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your
back straight. Raise your right arm forward, finishing with your arm in line
with your body. Send energy all the way up your spine and out through your arm
and hand. Relax and return to the starting position. Repeat with the other arm.

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your
weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your
back straight. Raise your right arm forward, finishing with your arm in line
with your body. Send energy all the way up your spine and out through your arm
and hand. Relax and return to the starting position. Repeat with the other arm.

posts.title: Upper and Mid Back Range of Motion
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"_These exercises should only be performed after evaluation by a qualified medical professional and under their instruction. Should you experience pain or discomfort while doing an exercise, stop immediately._ 


<video width="640" controls >
  <source src="https://assets.imatrix.com/videos/chiro/back/upper_and_mid_back_range_of_motion/upper_and_mid_back_range_of_motion_hd.webm" type="video/webm" />
  <source src="https://assets.imatrix.com/videos/chiro/back/upper_and_mid_back_range_of_motion/upper_and_mid_back_range_of_motion_hd.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
  <source src="https://assets.imatrix.com/videos/chiro/back/upper_and_mid_back_range_of_motion/upper_and_mid_back_range_of_motion_hd.ogv" type="video/ogg" />
  Your browser doesn't support HTML5 video tag.
</video>

---

### Upper and Mid Back Range of Motion

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your back straight.

Next, imagine you're reaching energy up through the top of your head and arch up through your neck, upper shoulders, and upper back. Let the movement continue through your mid-back and imagine you're bringing your shoulder blades together. You're keeping your stomach muscles activated throughout this movement. You'll feel the muscular contraction in your upper and mid-back. Relax and return to the starting position.

Next, initiating the movement in your stomach muscles, round through your mid- and upper back, continuing the movement through your neck and letting your head round down. You'll feel the muscular contraction across your upper and mid-back. Relax and return to the starting position."}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
These exercises should only be performed after evaluation by a qualified medical professional and under their instruction. Should you experience pain or discomfort while doing an exercise, stop immediately.

Upper and Mid Back Range of Motion

Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your back straight.

Next, imagine you're reaching energy up through the top of your head and arch up through your neck, upper shoulders, and upper back. Let the movement continue through your mid-back and imagine you're bringing your shoulder blades together. You're keeping your stomach muscles activated throughout this movement. You'll feel the muscular contraction in your upper and mid-back. Relax and return to the starting position.

Next, initiating the movement in your stomach muscles, round through your mid- and upper back, continuing the movement through your neck and letting your head round down. You'll feel the muscular contraction across your upper and mid-back. Relax and return to the starting position.
posts.plaintext:
These exercises should only be performed after evaluation by a qualified medical
professional and under their instruction. Should you experience pain or
discomfort while doing an exercise, stop immediately.

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 video tag.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Upper and Mid Back Range of Motion
Your starting position is on your hands and knees on an exercise mat. Your
weight is evenly balanced. Keep your stomach muscles activated and keep your
back straight.

Next, imagine you're reaching energy up through the top of your head and arch up
through your neck, upper shoulders, and upper back. Let the movement continue
through your mid-back and imagine you're bringing your shoulder blades together.
You're keeping your stomach muscles activated throughout this movement. You'll
feel the muscular contraction in your upper and mid-back. Relax and return to
the starting position.

Next, initiating the movement in your stomach muscles, round through your mid-
and upper back, continuing the movement through your neck and letting your head
round down. You'll feel the muscular contraction across your upper and mid-back.
Relax and return to the starting position.

posts.title: Avoid Pain and Injury During Yard Work
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Gardening is one of the most challenging activities for your spine. It is among the leading causes for lower back pain and even disc herniation! This activity requires you to work in a bent position, which negatively impacts your low back mechanics. It will leave you with that nasty lower back pain making you search desperately for a solution.

Repetitive raking, planting, and digging can also leave you with shoulder, knee and hip pain.  This is usually related to prolonged bad posture, which is unfortunately required to garden properly. Our body is simply not designed for this. The worst part is that the pain rarely occurs while gardening, rather it shows up during the night, the following day, or later in the week.

## Warm Up
Before you begin any extended periods of outdoor work, prepare with a five to ten minute warm up. A combination of slow, bigger body movements and stretching is a great start. Some simple yet very effective tools for you include [body squats](https://youtu.be/UXJrBgI2RxA), [hamstring stretches](https://youtu.be/bOf2AOpG4qM), [shoulder exercises](https://youtu.be/h8H2fEMlVfI), and [spine rotations](https://youtu.be/wqWcngCTQf0).

## Take Breaks
The truth is that there are so many folks who come to the chiropractic office on Monday after a weekend of yard work and they are in a significant amount of pain. Can you relate?

Aside from not warming up, one of the next biggest mistakes is extended periods of time with no rest. It is easy to lose track of time when you are focused on finishing the yard. Unfortunately, this degrades the health of your spine and increases your pain levels.

Make sure that you are not continuing repetitive motions. Moving your body in different ways can help. This means if you are consistently raking and rotated to the left, stop to do a simple body squat, take a drink of water, and when you restart, rake rotated to the right.

Every hour make sure you take a ten minute break. Cap the number of hours you do total throughout the day based on your fitness and health levels.

## Get Adjusted
Being able to perform these daily activities of living require that your spine is as healthy as possible. If you wish to not have significant repercussions after the fact, your spinal joints must move as fluidly through their full range of motion for optimal flexibility, mobility and nervous system communication. Chiropractic adjustments provide proper spinal joint motion that helps lead to increased flexibility, mobility, proper muscle activity and nervous system communication. The chiropractic adjustment is a weapon in your arsenal. Use it. Ideally, get your spine checked and adjusted prior to and after your long stints of yard work. Weekly adjustments help ensure that you are almost always in optimal condition.

The seasons are cyclical, as is the stress we put on our spine and body. Let me help you keep your spine safe and functioning optimally throughout the summer and beyond."}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Gardening is one of the most challenging activities for your spine. It is among the leading causes for lower back pain and even disc herniation! This activity requires you to work in a bent position, which negatively impacts your low back mechanics. It will leave you with that nasty lower back pain making you search desperately for a solution.

Repetitive raking, planting, and digging can also leave you with shoulder, knee and hip pain. This is usually related to prolonged bad posture, which is unfortunately required to garden properly. Our body is simply not designed for this. The worst part is that the pain rarely occurs while gardening, rather it shows up during the night, the following day, or later in the week.

Warm Up

Before you begin any extended periods of outdoor work, prepare with a five to ten minute warm up. A combination of slow, bigger body movements and stretching is a great start. Some simple yet very effective tools for you include body squats, hamstring stretches, shoulder exercises, and spine rotations.

Take Breaks

The truth is that there are so many folks who come to the chiropractic office on Monday after a weekend of yard work and they are in a significant amount of pain. Can you relate?

Aside from not warming up, one of the next biggest mistakes is extended periods of time with no rest. It is easy to lose track of time when you are focused on finishing the yard. Unfortunately, this degrades the health of your spine and increases your pain levels.

Make sure that you are not continuing repetitive motions. Moving your body in different ways can help. This means if you are consistently raking and rotated to the left, stop to do a simple body squat, take a drink of water, and when you restart, rake rotated to the right.

Every hour make sure you take a ten minute break. Cap the number of hours you do total throughout the day based on your fitness and health levels.

Get Adjusted

Being able to perform these daily activities of living require that your spine is as healthy as possible. If you wish to not have significant repercussions after the fact, your spinal joints must move as fluidly through their full range of motion for optimal flexibility, mobility and nervous system communication. Chiropractic adjustments provide proper spinal joint motion that helps lead to increased flexibility, mobility, proper muscle activity and nervous system communication. The chiropractic adjustment is a weapon in your arsenal. Use it. Ideally, get your spine checked and adjusted prior to and after your long stints of yard work. Weekly adjustments help ensure that you are almost always in optimal condition.

The seasons are cyclical, as is the stress we put on our spine and body. Let me help you keep your spine safe and functioning optimally throughout the summer and beyond.
posts.plaintext:
Gardening is one of the most challenging activities for your spine. It is among
the leading causes for lower back pain and even disc herniation! This activity
requires you to work in a bent position, which negatively impacts your low back
mechanics. It will leave you with that nasty lower back pain making you search
desperately for a solution.

Repetitive raking, planting, and digging can also leave you with shoulder, knee
and hip pain. This is usually related to prolonged bad posture, which is
unfortunately required to garden properly. Our body is simply not designed for
this. The worst part is that the pain rarely occurs while gardening, rather it
shows up during the night, the following day, or later in the week.

Warm Up
Before you begin any extended periods of outdoor work, prepare with a five to
ten minute warm up. A combination of slow, bigger body movements and stretching
is a great start. Some simple yet very effective tools for you include body
squats [https://youtu.be/UXJrBgI2RxA], hamstring stretches
[https://youtu.be/bOf2AOpG4qM], shoulder exercises
[https://youtu.be/h8H2fEMlVfI], and spine rotations
[https://youtu.be/wqWcngCTQf0].

Take Breaks
The truth is that there are so many folks who come to the chiropractic office on
Monday after a weekend of yard work and they are in a significant amount of
pain. Can you relate?

Aside from not warming up, one of the next biggest mistakes is extended periods
of time with no rest. It is easy to lose track of time when you are focused on
finishing the yard. Unfortunately, this degrades the health of your spine and
increases your pain levels.

Make sure that you are not continuing repetitive motions. Moving your body in
different ways can help. This means if you are consistently raking and rotated
to the left, stop to do a simple body squat, take a drink of water, and when you
restart, rake rotated to the right.

Every hour make sure you take a ten minute break. Cap the number of hours you do
total throughout the day based on your fitness and health levels.

Get Adjusted
Being able to perform these daily activities of living require that your spine
is as healthy as possible. If you wish to not have significant repercussions
after the fact, your spinal joints must move as fluidly through their full range
of motion for optimal flexibility, mobility and nervous system communication.
Chiropractic adjustments provide proper spinal joint motion that helps lead to
increased flexibility, mobility, proper muscle activity and nervous system
communication. The chiropractic adjustment is a weapon in your arsenal. Use it.
Ideally, get your spine checked and adjusted prior to and after your long stints
of yard work. Weekly adjustments help ensure that you are almost always in
optimal condition.

The seasons are cyclical, as is the stress we put on our spine and body. Let me
help you keep your spine safe and functioning optimally throughout the summer
and beyond.

Includes filter body, inlet hose and outlet hose that fit standard pipes, quick clip, and screw. Leak free!"],[1,[],0,34],[0,[],0," "],[1,[],0,35],[0,[],0,"Woder 10K-DC comes as a complete assembled kit."],[1,[],0,36],[0,[],0," "],[1,[],0,37],[0,[],0,"Includes: Filter body, inlet hose - 3/8 female compression by 1/4 standard pipe thread, outlet hose- 3/8 m compression by 1/4 standard pipe, clip and screw. "]]],[10,6],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"FINEST MATERIALS"],[1,[],0,38],[0,[],0," "]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Woder filters are built with materials approved and tested by independent laboratories, so you can have complete confidence in the quality of Woder-filtered water."],[1,[],0,39]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[],0," Should I be concerned about total dissolved solids?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"All healthy water has a certain level of total dissolved solids. "],[1,[],0,40],[0,[],0," "]]],[10,7],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Unmatched Benefits"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"With a Woder filter, you’ll enjoy:"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Unmatched Filtration Safe, pure – 99.9% free of contaminants Healthy drinking water – with essential minerals vital to your health Fresh-tasting water – as refreshing as spring water Healthier skin – naturally softer, smoother, and more beautiful Cleaner dishes – without watermarks from your tap water ."]]],[10,8],[1,"p",[]]]}
posts.html:
ENJOY TAP WATER AS PURE AND HEALTHY AS SPRING WATER!                                                                                                                      

                                                                                                                      The Woder advantage – Selective Filtration

Woder filters have a unique technology that removes over 99.99% of contaminants while leaving in all essential minerals, which are vital to your health, including calcium, potassium, and magnesium. The unique advanced Selective Filtration technology has an affinity for  impurities, so it attracts them, but it has no affinity for healthy  minerals, so it allows them to remain.

Water as mother nature intended it to be


When your water is pure yet healthy with essential minerals, it’s the  way nature intended drinking water to be. By contrast, residential  filters that work with reverse osmosis filter out everything, including  the minerals your body needs for good health. As far as nutrition goes,  experts consider it essentially dead water.  

PURE AND HEALTHY WATER – WITH NO MORE BOTTLES IN THE FRIDGE
Eliminates lead (99.9%), heavy metals, chlorine (99.9%), chromium 6,  mercury, volatile organic compounds, carcinogens, and other  contaminants, as well as turbidity, odors and bad tastes. So you and  your family enjoy pure, healthy, spring-fresh water from the tap.

Much healthier than water filtered by reverse osmosis

Filters that work by reverse osmosis remove everything, even the  essential minerals. That’s why water filtered by RO is described by many  experts as “dead” water.

Woder-10K-DC - Longer lasting for superior value                            

Woder filters last for a minimum of 3 years with normal use. That’s as much as 6 times longer than many filters.

Why?


Woder filters use micro-particles, so the filters contain far more  filtering ingredients. This difference gives them the highest capacity  to purify your water for years while they remain optimally effective.

PURE AND HEALTHY WATER – WITH NO MORE BOTTLES IN THE FRIDGE

PLEASE NOTE:​​

Use with municipal treated cold water only

For longest life, do not use with salty or softened water. Do not use with well water. Do not use with hot water.

Woder filters have a unique technology that removes over 99.99% of contaminants while leaving in all essential minerals

What are essential minerals?
 

Essential minerals are ingredients that your body does not produce  naturally but that are  necessary for your health and well being. They  include:
 
Calcium – Your body  needs calcium to build strong bones and teeth. Calcium also plays a role  in nerve transmissions, muscle function -- including that of the heart  -- and hormone secretion.
 
Potassium – Potassium  controls the electrical activity of your heart, making it vital to  maintaining a normal heart rhythm. Your body also needs it to build  proteins, break down and use carbohydrates, maintain the pH balance of  the blood and support normal growth.
 
Sodium – Although  too much sodium can increase your risk for developing high blood  pressure, your body needs sodium to stimulate nerve and muscle function,  maintain the correct balance of fluid in the cells and support the  absorption of other nutrients including chloride, amino acids and  glucose.
 
Magnesium – Your  body needs magnesium to support more than 300 biochemical reactions.  Magnesium supports muscle and nerve function, keeps your heart beating  regularly, builds strong bones and boosts immunity
 
Phosphorus – Phosphorus plays an important role in building strong bones and teeth, producing proteins the body needs and repairing cells.
 
Chloride – Chloride,  usually consumed as a salt compound such as sodium chloride -- better  known as table salt -- balances the fluids in your body and plays an  essential role in the production of digestive juices in the stomach.

                                                                                                                                                                   WODER PREMIUM WATER FILTERS - Enjoy pure, healthy water on tap                                                                                                                                          

ALL SET IN FIVE TO TEN MINUTES


Woder 10K-DC comes with everything you need to install it in minutes.  Includes filter body, inlet hose and outlet hose that fit standard  pipes, quick clip, and screw. Leak free!

Woder 10K-DC comes as a complete assembled kit.

Includes: Filter body, inlet hose - 3/8 female compression by 1/4  standard pipe thread, outlet hose- 3/8 m compression by 1/4 standard  pipe, clip and screw.                                                                                                                                                          

FINEST MATERIALS

Woder filters are built with materials approved  and tested by  independent laboratories, so you can have complete confidence in the  quality of Woder-filtered water.

Should I be concerned about total dissolved solids?

All healthy water has a certain level of total dissolved solids. These are the essential minerals. So TDS meters are not an effective way to measure water quality.  In fact, water without any TDSs is considered “dead” water and not healthy for drinking. It is most often produced by reverse osmosis.
                                                                                                                                                           

Unmatched Benefits

With a Woder filter, you’ll enjoy:

Unmatched Filtration Safe, pure – 99.9% free of contaminants Healthy drinking water – with essential minerals vital to your health Fresh-tasting water – as refreshing as spring water Healthier skin – naturally softer, smoother, and more beautiful Cleaner dishes – without watermarks from your tap water .

<style>
.site-logo, .site-description {
 	display: none;
}
.site-nav-logo img {
    display: block;
    width: auto;
    height: 30px;
}
.site-nav-logo {
    flex-shrink: 0;
    display: block;
    margin-right: 24px;
    padding: 11px 0;
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 1.7rem;
    line-height: 1em;
    font-weight: bold;
    letter-spacing: -0.5px;
}
.floating-header-logo img {
    margin: 3em;
    max-height: 9rem;
}
.site-header {
    position: relative;
    color: #fff;
    background: #090a0b no-repeat 50%;
    background-size: cover;
}

users.bio: I'm a Software Engineer focused on helping companies scale. I love learning about software architecture, JavaScript, open source programming and automation.
